results.title: The English inn
results.creator_credit: Muriel Baker, James Carr, Sydney Box and Verity Films
results.brief_description: The inn is the centre of life in the towns and villages of England. Carved designs and paintings by artists of long ago can still be seen today in these inns. Most of the more pretentious inns were built along the old coaching routes, where they formed a vital part of the communication system.

results.title: The Engineering of agreement. What would you say?
results.creator_credit: Jodie Copelan, Leon S. Gold and Roundtable Productions
results.brief_description: Obtaining the agreement of others is vital in the everyday work situation and in such fields as sales; the value of considering the other person’s point of view and of establishing two way communication. Two real-life interviews show the right and wrong approaches, while a trailer provides opportunities for discussing common difficulties.

results.title: The Engineer and the atom
results.brief_description: The role of engineers in a series of atomic projects, including Calder Hall, Dounreay, and the new series of stations being built for the Electricity Authority are featured. The need for new techniques in building skill, using a greater degree of precision than ever before, and new materials capable of standing up to intense strain and powerful radiation is emphasised. No other credits available.

results.title: The Energy crunch: the nuclear dilemma
results.creator_credit: Patrick Uden, Lawrence Wade and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Explores the possibility of using nuclear energy for the safe production of electricity. Shows the increasing demand for power that cannot be met by the current available resources. States the potential dangers involved in switching to nuclear power

results.title: The Energy crisis
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Review: 26th year”.
An examination of how Britain’s way of life was affected by the patterns of energy supply. The film makes a forecast for the future.

results.title: The Enduring wilderness
results.brief_description: A scenic tour of Canada’s national parks, from the mountains of British Columbia to the seaswept shores of Newfoundland. Besides the beauty of the unspoiled wilderness (and there is much of that), you see also the farsightedness of those who in the past century, set aside these territories for the enjoyment of future generations.

results.title: The End of St Petersburg = Konyets Sankt-Peterburga [DVD]
results.brief_description: Originally made to commemorate the tenth year of the overthrow of Czarist Russia, Pudovkin’s film tells the story of a peasant boy who comes to St. Petersburg in search of work and witnesses the October Revolution. Set against the background of the historical events which culminated in the attack on the Winter Palace, the film contains graphic anti-war statements and was so realistically shot, that some interpreted the footage as documentary evidence of real events. Despite numerous crowd scenes, Pudovkin focuses on the struggle of the individual to relay the concerns of a people. Contains striking black and white cinematography, and expressionistic performances from Alexander Chistyakov and Vera Baranovska. Based on the poem, “The Bronze horseman” by Pushkin and the novel “St Petersburg” by Andrev Biely.

results.title: The Encircling sea
results.brief_description: No part of New Zealand is very far from the sea and as a result it has become part of the lives of the inhabitants. Many are engaged in the fishing industry; boating and sailing are popular pastimes; and the numerous beaches within easy reach of the city dweller, provide opportunities for swimming and relaxation.
